text: Slappy's hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internets busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
sleigh bells reign of terror sleigh
bells is a new york poppin rock duo and
this is their sophomore LP the band is
pretty much singer Alexis Krauss and
guitar player Derek Miller and I've been
getting a lot of requests to talk about
this LP not only because this band has
been getting a lot of buzz this year but
I have kind of a troubled past with
sleigh bells I think I'm gonna come out
and say their previous material has not
exactly received glowing reviews from
yours truly but it's whatever
I wasn't huge on this band's debut LP
treats but I will give it to this album
for just being extremely extremely loud
a really brittle ear-shattering style of
loud it was just a combination of these
early tinny distorted guitar riffs
matched up with shouted female vocals
and some really really compressed heavy
drum machine beats all the melodies the
emotions the songs just felt really
really simple and in a way they had to
be because I can't imagine a complicated
or detailed song translating all that
well through the extremely loud and low
Phi recording that sleigh bells
subjected its music to on trees this
helped me definitely reached a new
threshold of volume for pop music but I
wouldn't really go as far as to call it
experimental or trailblazing or anything
like that because a lot of the songs on
here were just so so shallow that the
volume and the recording style just kind
of ended up sounding like a gimmick it
was really the only unique thing it had
going now the sophomore LP reign of
terror is here and I definitely commend
these guys for tweaking their sound up a
bit they have pulled their recording a
style out of the lo-fi doldrum
they've created a set of tracks that
actually tries to stand past the sound
that defined the debut album from these
guys and really kind of prove their
worth but overall I think sleighbells
pretty much just ended up with a better
recorded version of their last album a
lot of the melodies on these songs even
resemble melodies from the previous
album and the sounds they're working
with are still roughly the same the
distorted tinny guitars the really cheap
heavy drum machine beats the light
breathy girly vocal delivery one of the
few sounds on here that I caused being
kind of new kind of fresh where these
shouted background vocals kind of like
in a chorus or in unison they kind of
sounded like vocals a group of
cheerleaders would scream their samples
of roaring crowds just screaming as if
sleighbells is like indie Pop's answer
to arena rock and in a way I could see
them being that because they definitely
go for a loud bombastic over-the-top
sound a lot like bands such as kiss did
in their heyday and like kiss sleigh
bells really tries to push an image to
the last thing I was catching on here
that felt kind of new was just all these
layers of guitars because the mix is
less lo-fi less claustrophobic this time
around there's just more space to throw
in harmonized guitar solos a little bit
of riff counterpoint I guess some whammy
bar solos though it is clearer it's
still loud too loud and abrasive for
commercial radio but still tries to
shoot for that same kind of candy-coated
accessibility this album is pretty much
abrasive only because of the guitars and
if you replace them with synthesizers or
something like that I don't really see
any reason this album couldn't get
played on any commercial radio station
even like Radio Disney even though I
think this LP is just a variation on the
previous album I did end up liking it
more
and it let me see sleighbells music in a
slightly different light it's not
exactly winning my heart or anything but
the noise and the beats and in the hooks
on this album in a way actually kind of
reminded me of Nine Inch Nails a little
bit you know except it's going for
something that's a lot more gum-chewing
hair twirling and shallow the whole
thing to me just ends up sounding like a
beer commercial you know it just feels
as flashy as a beer commercial when I
listen to this I just see bikini models
and hot waitresses and guys shotgunning
beers and like a bar band rocking out
the only difference with sleighbells
take on this is that the bikini models
may have some skull tattoos the waitress
may be wearing gold spandex American
Apparel tights and chain-smoking
the beers that are being shotgun der
Pabst Blue Ribbon and the band that's
playing might be wearing some Wayfarers
and Ramones t-shirts still the new
recording that sleighbells is working
with in my opinion though it kind of
takes the uniqueness away from this duo
it does make their music a lot more
listenable the beginning of this LP to
me just kind of felt like usual sleigh
bells but the end of this album cooled
off a bit tone things down and I ended
up liking it which isn't too much of a
surprise since from the previous LP
songs like rill rill were my favorites
songs like DOA which is kind of like
sleigh bells attempt at a valid and then
road to hell which was pretty repetitive
but very kind of alluring and sexy those
tracks to me come off waist sweeter than
the ones with just the the insanely loud
guitars and it's not even that it's loud
it's just that what the guitars are
playing on tracks like born to lose
toward the end of the track or demons
the riffs just sounds so immature they
sound like riffs that you play on your
tiny little practice amp but the
distortion button turned on and turned
all the way up there are some
improvements that I'm noticing with this
LP and
that is making me like this album in
this bands music a lot more but not so
much that I'm just totally head over
heels for it sleigh bells has their own
style and as long as they have that it's
going to attract fans it's going to
catch ears and it's going to stop people
in their tracks and that's always a good
thing I'm kind of feeling like a strong
five to a light six on this but what do
you guys think about it do you love it
do you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantana sleigh bells
forever
[Music]
[Music]
